text: My roommate says primes run out after some huge number and the textbooks are just repeating a myth. Should I push back hard or let it go?

Euclid’s proof (simple and standard)
- Suppose, for contradiction, the primes are finite and the list of all of them is p1, p2, …, pn.
- Form N = p1 · p2 · … · pn + 1.
- Every pi divides p1·p2·…·pn, so none of the pi can divide N (because dividing both terms on the right would force pi to divide 1, impossible).
- So N has no prime factor from the list p1,…,pn. But every integer > 1 has a prime factor, so N either is a new prime or has a prime factor outside the list — contradiction.
- Therefore there are infinitely many primes.

Quick intuition: multiplying all known primes and adding 1 produces a number that is “one more” than something divisible by every known prime, so a new prime must appear.

If you want more:
- Euler gave another proof using the divergence of the sum of reciprocals of primes.
- Primes do get rarer: the density ~ 1 / log n (Prime Number Theorem), but “rarer” ≠ “finite.”

How to handle the roommate
- If they’re joking or not interested, let it go.
- If they’re serious and want a discussion, ask them to present their argument; then show Euclid’s proof — it’s short and decisive.
- If you want a non-confrontational line: “That’d be a big discovery — show me the proof.” Most claims that “textbooks are lying” don’t survive that challenge.
